trustfund:
TF094952-Moldova Regional Development
            and Social Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Regional Development
            Project for Moldova were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Grantee performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: on the Government side, using
            existing Project Implementation Units (PIUs) while assuring
            that they have the capacity to deliver and absorb the extra
            work can be an efficient way to leverage existing government
            structures and reduce administrative cost. Since funds for
            the project were tied to the financing agreement between the
            European Commission (EC) and Moldova, its extension was
            restricted to the duration of the later, which meant that
            grant funds went unused, and the government had to increase
            its contribution at a time of fiscal contraction. A detailed
            reporting mechanism that allowed the Bank to inform the EC
            on the status of project implementation and meets
            donor's expectations should be agreed upon during
            preparation. There is a need to integrate approach to
            dealing with water issues in the design of social investment
            funds with water sub-projects particularly in the case of
            community driven development programs. Households
            re-affirmed their willingness to pay for improved water
            supply, share connecting costs, have meters installed, and
            cover monthly payments for piped water connections. Moldova
            Social Investment Fund (MSIF) contributions were capped at
            United States (U.S.) 75,000 dollars. As a result, the fund
            was able to more significantly impact smaller rather than
            larger villages. Experience in the procurement of the road
            rehabilitation section where the total investment was
            considered too low to attract international bidders but the
            amount required to use International Competitive Bidding
            (ICB) revealed the importance of assessing sector entry
            costs and procurement guidelines to define investment amounts.
